intro: Eremophila macgillivrayi, commonly known as the Macgillivray's bushfire wattle, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of Western Australia. It is a shrub that typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 meters, featuring woody stems and small, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of bright yellow, pea-like flowers during the winter and spring months. It is adapted to harsh, dry environments and has a deep root system to access groundwater. Eremophila macgillivrayi is part of the Myrtaceae family and is known for its ecological importance in supporting local wildlife.
